title: Google ads promote risky investments which 'could mislead savers', warns consumer group
text:
Google is promoting adverts for high-risk investments that may mislead savers looking for safer options, an investigation by Which? has found.

The consumer group found those using search terms like "best cash Isa" and "cash Isa comparison" were shown products with high fixed returns and no mention of risk by the search giant.

Which? showed savers a selection of Google paid-for ads, at the top of the results page marked as "promoted". While just under a third were drawn to a cash Isa from Nationwide, 34 per cent were attracted to offerings from two unknown firms' riskier, high-return options. Which? said the pair's ads did not include sufficient risk information.

The Daily Telegraph has previously revealed that Google's algorithm was pushing investors specifically seeking a low level of risk towards firms offering high, double-digit returns that come with a high level of risk.

Jenny Ross, of Which?, said: “It’s concerning to see that despite thousands of savers losing millions as a result of risky, unregulated investments, savers are continuing to be confused and misled as a result of ads omitting crucial information about risk.”

A Google spokesman said: "Because we want the ads people see on Google to be useful and relevant, we have policies that govern the ads that are allowed to run on our platforms. If we discover ads in breach, we quickly take action."
description: Google is promoting adverts for high-risk investments that may mislead savers looking for safer options, an investigation by Which?
